title: Obeying an erroneous High Court
vignette: The Supreme Court mistakenly rules a forbidden fat permissible. Reuven knows it is wrong yet eats it.

options.text: Reuven is liable; personal knowledge trumps obedience.
Reuven is exempt; deference to the Court absolves him.

title: Court retracts—who brings the sin-offering?
vignette: The High Court issues a mistaken ruling, some act on it, then the Court rescinds. Must it still bring the communal offering?

options.text: Yes; responsibility remains despite retraction.
No; correction wipes out liability.

title: Anointed Priest vs. Court—overlapping errors
vignette: Both the High Priest and the Court rule mistakenly and act. Should each bring a separate offering or only one?

options.text: Each brings his own; leaders answer individually.
Single communal offering suffices; avoid duplication.

title: Liability when following a local court
vignette: A provincial court errs. Citizens follow its ruling, later overruled by the Supreme Court.

options.text: Citizens liable; they should verify with Jerusalem.
Citizens exempt; they relied on their authorised judges.

title: Teacher exiled—who moves?
vignette: A Torah teacher is exiled to a refuge city for accidental killing. Must his pupils relocate to learn from him, or is he brought back under guard?

options.text: Move the pupils to him.
Escort the teacher home; minimise communal disruption.

title: King vs. High Priest—rescue priority
vignette: Both a king and a High Priest are drowning; only one can be saved.

options.text: Save the High Priest first.
Save the King first.

title: Torah scholar vs. King—rescue priority
vignette: A renowned Torah scholar and the reigning monarch are in mortal peril; you can aid only one.

options.text: Save the scholar first.
Save the king first.

title: Man vs. Woman—captivity release
vignette: A man and a woman are captured by pirates; funds suffice to redeem one.

options.text: Redeem the woman first (greater vulnerability).
Redeem the man first (traditional precedence).

title: Father vs. Teacher—lost object priority
vignette: You find both your father’s and your Torah teacher’s lost items. Which do you return first?

options.text: Return the teacher’s first (greater spiritual debt).
Return the father’s first (filial responsibility).

title: Providing relief—loading vs. unloading
vignette: Two travellers: one needs help loading his pack animal, the other unloading a fallen load. You can help only one.

options.text: Help unload first (immediate suffering).
Help load first (prior commitment/order).

title: Scholar mamzer vs. ignorant High Priest
vignette: A brilliant Torah scholar of illegitimate birth (mamzer) and an unlearned High Priest are both in mortal danger; only one can be rescued first.

options.text: Rescue the scholar mamzer first; Torah wisdom outweighs lineage.
Rescue the High Priest first; sacred office and pedigree demand priority.

title: Woman vs. man for clothing aid
vignette: A destitute woman and a destitute man each need a garment, but charity funds can clothe only one.

options.text: Clothe the woman first; her humiliation is considered greater.
Clothe the man first; distribute aid without gender preference.

title: Priest vs. Levite—rescue priority
vignette: A priest (*kohen*) and a Levite are both trapped under rubble; only one can be pulled out alive.

options.text: Rescue the priest first (higher sacred rank).
Rescue the Levite first (all lives equal; help the nearest).

title: Israelite vs. Mamzer—charity allocation
vignette: A penniless Israelite of regular lineage and a penniless *mamzer* (illegitimate birth) each request the last available charity loaf.

options.text: Give the loaf to the Israelite (ancestral standing).
Give it to the mamzer (all humans equal in need).

title: Convert vs. Freed Slave—captivity release
vignette: A convert to Judaism and a recently freed slave are both held for ransom; funds can redeem only one.

options.text: Redeem the convert first (full covenantal status).
Redeem the freed slave first (compassion for former oppression).
